Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 10:56AM Makratz wrote: I got the results of my biopsy 4 days afer my biopsy.  Oncotype DX is a test performed on your tumor (hopefully you don't have one!).  I had the Oncotype DX dx after my lumpectomy.  They splice the tumor and test it for 16 different things (I think it's 16).  They can tell alot from this test like how aggressive the tumor is and if you would benefit from Chemo or not.  Scoring is from 1-100.  You want a low score!  I got a 15 and found out I wouln't benefit that much from chemo, so I did not do it. Best of luck to you.  I'm glad you found this website.  It's scary, but you've got a lot of support here.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 01:23AM Makratz wrote: Found this on facebook and wanted to share it with you all since we've al been there!  It's a poem about radiation therapy.......... The 3 Million Dollar Tanning Bed By: Kathy Negro/ Breast Cancer Warrior I walk into the office with apprehension and fear The diagnosis of cancer is what we all share Radiation is needed for 6 weeks and 3 days Completed my chemo and now it's this phase The entire staff is filled with compassion and care They make you feel as if they've known you for years A mold is made from my chest to my head To prevent me from moving and being misread The next step seems to be exciting and new Not one, not two but many small tattoos The first day of treatment seems so surreal The patients you meet know how you feel It is time for radiation from the 3 million dollar tanning bed You get on the table and gently lay down your head You look up and the ceiling is filled with flowers galore Your heart starts to beat and you feel anxiety to the core The staff aligns you and each exits the room It feels like you're awaiting some impending doom I lie there alone and start to pray It is painless, this so called radiation ray Each visit gets easier and the staff becomes friends Fear, apprehension and anxiety all begin to end Yes, the skin can get red, blister and peel But doctors will take care of anything you feel These words are my gift of appreciation and gratitude For encouraging me to always have a positive attitude Each day I walk in, I smile as I have learned to cope This office has given me care, kindness, but most of all hope. From the front desk to the doctor to each one of you I am so grateful and proud of the job that you do

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 10:00AM Makratz wrote: Lisa and Luah,  I'm so glad you found BCO.  I found this website to be so helpful to me while I was going through my tests, surgeries etc.  There are so many wonderful ladies (and  a few men) who are willing to help you. Lisa, I'm sure you are going nuts and your imagination is getting the best of you. Your doc is doing these tests to be certain it hasn't gone anywhere else.  Isee you have IDC, were you lymph nodes tested?  If so were they positive? Do you have a list of questions to ask your breast surgeon?  Is someone going with you?   recommend they do because your head will be so full with info, you'll be confused and unsure of what he/she said.  Take notes, lots of them.  I assume they will do the node biopsy at the time of lump/msc.  Then they sent it out to pathology to determine what treatment you should have.  Hang in there, alot of your questions should be answered tomorrow. Luah, a breast MRI is just like any other MRI but your boobs get put through two holes and the MRI is done that way.  You lay down on your stomach.  No pain, just noisy!  Make sure they give you ear plugs.   I truly hope yours is nothing.  Remember 70% are B9. Good luck to both of you.  If I can help with your questions, please don't hesitate to ask. Linda

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 04:50PM Makratz wrote: You're survival rate depends on so many things.  Breast cancer (BC) is highly treatable today.  I have been where you are and was freaking out too.  So many of us have been there.  There are women on these boards that are 5, 10, 15, 20, 30 year survivors!!  YEAH!!  Most breast lumps are benign too.  It's great that your doctor found it and they are checking it out. You should be confused, there are so many questions, so much to learn.  Just take it slow and take one day at a time.  I found it very helpful to bring someone to your appointments with you.  SInce you are nervous to begin with, you probably won't remember 90% of what they tell you.  I was dx 6-3-08 at 42.  I am looking forward to celebrating my one year anniversay in June.  I plan on being here for MANY MANY more years.  5 years, no way!!  I'm going for 50!! Best of luck to you!

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2010 07:16AM Makratz wrote: Tiffany, I felt exactly the same way that you do.  I'm sure a lot of us do.  One thing I have learned is that our friends and family want this to be over for us.  Of course they do.  BUT, as you stated, it will never be over.  We need to learn to adjust our lives to deak with the anxiety and frustration.  It can be done, it just takes time.  The best thing for me was to find this website and make the friends that I have.  These women unserstand everything that we have gone through.  You can laugh, cry, and vent any time! I also have anxiety medication that I take as needed.  Some weeks I never use it.  But if I have a bad week (mams, mris etc) then I can take the med to help ease my mind.  Lots of women do that and it certainly helps. You can get surgery consults and appointments really fast.  I was amazed.  I had my biopsy and was diagnosed with cancer 3 days later.  My surgery was 3 weeks later.  I also know people who wait  several months from diagnosis to surgery.  Every case is different and every hospital is too. It's important for you to remember that most (80%) of breast lumps are B9!  I'm sure someone with fibroadenoma will be answering you soon.  Hang in there.  Sending hugs your way.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2008 07:59PM Makratz wrote: HI Phylly8, I have not used either of those creams, but I have read about Jeans Cream in other forums.  People seemed to like it.  I use Aquaphor, which is vaseline like and kind of uncomfortable but works well.  I also use 100% aloe vera gel which I got at CVS and it works well.  You can put it in the fridge for extra sooting relief.  A friend just bought me a new cream called ALRA from Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston.  I LOVE this stuff.  Its 100% pure aloe vera, lanolin and a couple other ingredients.  It's specifically made for radiation treatments.  I think you can get it online too.  It's more creamy than the other 2 options I mentioned and is easier to get dressed with after being applied.  I am  going for my 22 treatment tomorrow and have faithfully put one of the mentions creams on my 2-4 times a day, every day.  I really think that that is key to keeping your skin  comfortable.  Good luck and do a search for jeans cream on the discussion boards above.  I'm sure you'll be able to find the others comments.  Good luck!
